Hit Points.At Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per druid level after 1st

Proficiencies.Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields (druids will not wear armor or use shields made of metal)
Proficiencies.Weapons: Clubs, daggers, darts, javelins, maces, quarterstaffs, scimitars, sickles, slings, spears
Proficiencies.Skills: Choose two from Arcana, Animal Handling, Insight, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Religion, and Survival

Starting Equipment: (a) a wooden shield or (b) any simple weapon
(a) a scimitar or (b) any simple melee weapon
(a) an explorer's pack or (b) a druid's pack

Class Features.Description: The Druid Spell List has been revised and expanded.
You gain proficiency with the Herbalism kit. You also learn the Druidic language, which allows you to understand the language and the script used by druids. Additionally, you can speak with animals.
At 1st level, you choose a Primal Order that shapes your connection to the natural world, granting you features at 2nd, 6th, 10th, and 14th levels. Choose from the following options:

Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Wild Shape as a bonus action. Additionally, while in beast form during Wild Shape, you can speak using your own voice, even if the beast form cannot normally speak.
You can use your Wild Shape feature to cast Find Familiar as a ritual.
At 3rd level, you choose a circle that binds you to the natural world, shaping your spellcasting and granting you features. Choose from the following circles:
At 4th level, you can transform into a beast with a challenge rating as high as 1 (you can’t transform into a beast that can fly or swim).

When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace one cantrip you learned from this class’s Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the druid spell list.
Starting at 5th level, you can expend a spell slot to regain one use of Wild Shape. Additionally, you can expend a use of Wild Shape to restore one level 1 spell slot during a long rest.
At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Druid Subclass.

At 7th level, you choose between Potent Spellcasting or Primal Strike. Potent Spellcasting allows you to add your Wisdom modifier to the damage dealt by your Druid cantrips. Primal Strike allows your attacks to deal an extra 1d8 Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder damage once per turn.
At 8th level, you can transform into a beast with a challenge rating as high as 1 (you can transform into a beast that can fly or swim).

When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace one cantrip you learned from this class’s Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the druid spell list.
Starting at 9th level, you can use your Wild Shape to transform into creatures with the ability to fly or swim. Additionally, you no longer need to expend a spell slot to use Wild Shape.
At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Druid Subclass.

At 11th level, you can expend a use of Wild Shape to assume the form of an elemental (Air, Earth, Fire, or Water) with a challenge rating equal to or lower than your druid level divided by 4 (rounded down).

When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace one cantrip you learned from this class’s Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the druid spell list.
At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Druid Subclass.

Starting at 15th level, your mastery of Wild Shape allows you to use it as a reaction to take half damage from any attack or spell, provided the damage is not psychic. This ability can be used once per short or long rest.

When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace one cantrip you learned from this class’s Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the druid spell list.

At 17th level, your Archdruid Mastery feature improves. You can now use Wild Shape as a reaction to negate the effects of one spell or attack that would otherwise deal damage to you, once per long rest.
Starting at 18th level, you can cast spells while in Wild Shape form.
Starting at 18th level, the primal magic that you wield causes you to age more slowly. For every 10 years that pass, your body ages only 1 year.

When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace one cantrip you learned from this class’s Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the druid spell list.
At 19th level, you receive one Epic Boon feat or another feat of your choice.

At 20th level, you regain one expended use of Wild Shape when you roll initiative, if you have no uses of Wild Shape remaining. Additionally, you can spend a spell slot once per day to regain one use of Wild Shape.
